results.content: This course teaches Django in good depth, but it is not a proper course for learning how to code. There are many inconsistencies throughout the course. The coding practices are awful, and the instructor code whatever he feels. Furthermore, there are tons of videos that repeat the same content without a purpose. The course is not well structured either.  In summary, I think this course needs a lot of improvement, and actually confuse the learner on how to code properly. I DO NOT recommend this course to anyone who is starting as a coder.

response.content:
We do not have redundant code, we have used proper variable naming convention for URLs, models & views. Hence I do not understand what you would mean by "coding practices are awful".
There isn't any repetition, we have built 6 web applications in the course and hence some of the steps involved are common to those apps and hence have to be covered in each section, skipping them isn't optional.
However if you feel that the course does not meet your expectations the feel free to request a refund.
Thank you
- Ashutosh

results.content:
It's just an okay course, really more beginner level than a "Masterclass." Felt like we did things the less efficient way (relative to other tutorials). Certain basic steps were edited out, and there were frustrating gaps.

I was also expecting more of advanced learning of complicated topics like overriding CBVs and building dynamic url patterns, but very little of that was covered. Reliance on function-based views felt antiquated. Really no coverage of urls, slugs, live server deployment.

On the ecom tutorial, nearly a quarter of the functionality was written in javascript through localstorage, which was a waste of an opportunity to teach us more about creating user instances and saving data and retrieving data from the database. Why not move the user auth section into the ecom tutorial so that we can put it to use? Very odd

response.content:
Hello Jeremy, 

We have covered (CBV) class based views, its just that more preference was given to function based views as they are more flexible to work with.

The whole idea behind the E-com section was to show students how Django can be integrated with JavaScript which is extremely essential to know as Full-stack developer and no other course teaches this. We do store the data temporarily in the local storage before adding it to the cart because thats how efficient web apps are built, i.e save the data temporarily in the browser and only submit it to the database once to as to avoid the need to constantly communicate with the server.

However,  if you feel that this course does not meet your expectations then feel free to request for a refund.
response.content_html:
Hello Jeremy,

We have covered (CBV) class based views, its just that more preference was given to function based views as they are more flexible to work with.

The whole idea behind the E-com section was to show students how Django can be integrated with JavaScript which is extremely essential to know as Full-stack developer and no other course teaches this. We do store the data temporarily in the local storage before adding it to the cart because thats how efficient web apps are built, i.e save the data temporarily in the browser and only submit it to the database once to as to avoid the need to constantly communicate with the server.

However, if you feel that this course does not meet your expectations then feel free to request for a refund.

results.content_html:
It's just an okay course, really more beginner level than a "Masterclass." Felt like we did things the less efficient way (relative to other tutorials). Certain basic steps were edited out, and there were frustrating gaps.

I was also expecting more of advanced learning of complicated topics like overriding CBVs and building dynamic url patterns, but very little of that was covered. Reliance on function-based views felt antiquated. Really no coverage of urls, slugs, live server deployment.

On the ecom tutorial, nearly a quarter of the functionality was written in javascript through localstorage, which was a waste of an opportunity to teach us more about creating user instances and saving data and retrieving data from the database. Why not move the user auth section into the ecom tutorial so that we can put it to use? Very odd

results.content: I found this course to be a great primer for Django. The instructor provides not only incremental information that I found to be very useful, but his approach to development is also one that is employs the use of a front end framework, namely Bootstrap and he uses a segmented approach, showing how to hide Bootstrap and CSS and used it to provide a cohesive website look. I've emulated his example for an actual site and I've been able to grow it to fit the customer's needs without having to abandon the original framework. It's not a soup to nuts course but it's what I needed to get a website up and running with no Django experience, no CSS experience and limited HTML experience.
results.content_html: I found this course to be a great primer for Django. The instructor provides not only incremental information that I found to be very useful, but his approach to development is also one that is employs the use of a front end framework, namely Bootstrap and he uses a segmented approach, showing how to hide Bootstrap and CSS and used it to provide a cohesive website look. I've emulated his example for an actual site and I've been able to grow it to fit the customer's needs without having to abandon the original framework. It's not a soup to nuts course but it's what I needed to get a website up and running with no Django experience, no CSS experience and limited HTML experience.

results.content: For the ecommerce site, code has lots of mistakes. ex. You cannot paginate and search at the same time. you cannot display cart on pagination due to considering just current page etc... found another tutorial for a cart.

response.content:
Hello student, there seems to be a confusion.

For example, when you use pagination and go to page 2 and if you perform search, it is supposed to give you a result which includes items across all page and not only the page you are on.

I also rechecked if cart can be displayed on the paginated page and it does work fine.

Please kindly recheck your code and refer to the last lecture of the E-commerce section to correct your code.
If it still does not work well, do let me know in the Q&A section and I will help you out.

Thank you
Ashutosh
response.content_html:

results.content:
This is just my opinion but the instructor does not teach or use the PEP 8 standard guide (Yes, it is just a guide but all major companies follow it). He does not teach production standards with his approach to web development. Like the lack of using virtual environments, directory layout, layout for deployment while coding. If you are a beginner with the Django framework you want to be taught the way major companies expect. 
The good I like: The instructor does know Django and how it works and will teach you this. If the instructor would redo his approach and use PEP 8 standards along with production standards that major companies use then this course would be a great resource to learn from.

response.content:
PEP 8 is used to improve code readability and hence is used by companies which have a large codebase.
The code used in the course is of a way smaller size and hence it makes a little difference if we used PEP 8 or not. 
And we do cover virtual environment in the 12th section titled "Pagination, Virtual Environment & User Permissions. "
response.content_html:
PEP 8 is used to improve code readability and hence is used by companies which have a large codebase.
The code used in the course is of a way smaller size and hence it makes a little difference if we used PEP 8 or not.
And we do cover virtual environment in the 12th section titled "Pagination, Virtual Environment & User Permissions. "

The good I like: The instructor does know Django and how it works and will teach you this. If the instructor would redo his approach and use PEP 8 standards along with production standards that major companies use then this course would be a great resource to learn from.

results.content:
I have completed many other tutorial before like the Djangogirls before. They are interesting but at the end all I could create was a blog and nothing else. This tutorial actually cuts everything into pieces in order to understand, even for an amateur as mystelf.
But it is quite difficult to follow at some point because we don't have the code visible. Some of it is given on lecture 66 but for an instance I was blocked at lecture 56 and it is missing. Please consider using Git or equivalent instead.
Other than that 18 hours of training with a few website, it is pretty neat and impressive.
Also a comment, more on the form, but there are a couple language tics that makes it a bit hard to follow.
results.content_html:

But it is quite difficult to follow at some point because we don't have the code visible. Some of it is given on lecture 66 but for an instance I was blocked at lecture 56 and it is missing. Please consider using Git or equivalent instead.
Other than that 18 hours of training with a few website, it is pretty neat and impressive.
Also a comment, more on the form, but there are a couple language tics that makes it a bit hard to follow.

results.content:
The course covered a lot of ground, and there were some interesting projects. However, there were a number of problems with the course that reduced its rating quite a bit.
[1] A number of projects had significant bugs that stopped the code working as specified. 
[2] Some of the 3rd-party add-ons that were used no longer worked without modification, as the versions had been upgraded and new defaults introduced.
[3] The explanations of some of the concepts by the presenter wer quite confused at times.
[4] Some of the code and database designs were poor, and would introduce the learner developer to bad habits.
results.content_html:
The course covered a lot of ground, and there were some interesting projects. However, there were a number of problems with the course that reduced its rating quite a bit.
[1] A number of projects had significant bugs that stopped the code working as specified.
[2] Some of the 3rd-party add-ons that were used no longer worked without modification, as the versions had been upgraded and new defaults introduced.
[3] The explanations of some of the concepts by the presenter wer quite confused at times.
[4] Some of the code and database designs were poor, and would introduce the learner developer to bad habits.

I really had fun in this course, however there were many flaws, sometimes when you write the exact same thing as the tutor it wouldn't work, the time you have to wait to get an answer on questions is also very long (4 days+) and the sourcecode provided by the tutor is only half of the actual code which made it veryy hard to check and follow threw.

Either way i learned very much but, even though it was a bit depressing

Regarding the code, please refer the last lectures of each section for source code of the apps built.
Thank you
Ashutosh

results.content:
The course is good enough to learn the basics.
However, I would recommend the following improvements:
1) A lot of lessons feel like improvised, and the teacher needs to make a lot less typos and small mistakes which waste a lot of time.
2) The course would gain by having a lot more structure whereby the teacher begins by explaining the main concepts and tools which will be learned in the lessons, then showing them how to use those and then finally to review what was learned. Too much time is spent explaining new concepts in the code editor.
3) Too much time is spent on the same things (i.e. installing packages, basic formatting and project setup etc). At the end I could skip through a lot of modules because they were a replay of previous units. The course could be much more efficient by having only lessons introducing actual new topics, new tools and new libraries and enabling students to download the code through a GitHub account or similar.
4) The "e-commerce site" is a bit of a let-down. Indeed it looks like a e-commerce website, but a lot of aspects of a truly e-commerce website are not shown: how to take payments, how to receive a list of latest orders etc... To be fair those functionalities are pretty technical and complex and v. likely outside the scope of a beginner course. But then it would be better to advertise this as "e-commerce site front-end" or "introduction to e-commerce site". The mention of "building a e-commerce site" is a bit misleading.
5) Too much confusion in choosing the variable names, and the actual algorithms chosen are not the best. I can see how a beginner would be truly confused by this course.

Apologies to be that direct. At the end of the day, I learned a few things about Django and it was a good introduction - however the course could be so much better by making the above mentioned few changes!
results.content_html:
The course is good enough to learn the basics.
However, I would recommend the following improvements:
1) A lot of lessons feel like improvised, and the teacher needs to make a lot less typos and small mistakes which waste a lot of time.
2) The course would gain by having a lot more structure whereby the teacher begins by explaining the main concepts and tools which will be learned in the lessons, then showing them how to use those and then finally to review what was learned. Too much time is spent explaining new concepts in the code editor.
3) Too much time is spent on the same things (i.e. installing packages, basic formatting and project setup etc). At the end I could skip through a lot of modules because they were a replay of previous units. The course could be much more efficient by having only lessons introducing actual new topics, new tools and new libraries and enabling students to download the code through a GitHub account or similar.
4) The "e-commerce site" is a bit of a let-down. Indeed it looks like a e-commerce website, but a lot of aspects of a truly e-commerce website are not shown: how to take payments, how to receive a list of latest orders etc... To be fair those functionalities are pretty technical and complex and v. likely outside the scope of a beginner course. But then it would be better to advertise this as "e-commerce site front-end" or "introduction to e-commerce site". The mention of "building a e-commerce site" is a bit misleading.
5) Too much confusion in choosing the variable names, and the actual algorithms chosen are not the best. I can see how a beginner would be truly confused by this course.

Apologies to be that direct. At the end of the day, I learned a few things about Django and it was a good introduction - however the course could be so much better by making the above mentioned few changes!

results.content:
Great course that teaches you the concepts of Django and then through practice you get to learn them.

My only issue is that the coding practices regarding JavaScript are not excellent, but as long as you have a decent background with JavaScript, you should be fine! This is a Django course after all.
results.content_html:
Great course that teaches you the concepts of Django and then through practice you get to learn them.

My only issue is that the coding practices regarding JavaScript are not excellent, but as long as you have a decent background with JavaScript, you should be fine! This is a Django course after all.

results.content: Interesting and very thorough course. Created a number of different django applications that I can extend from in the future. Would have liked to have seen more examples of the class-based views as well as use of the extensions of base templates for the different web applications created.

results.content:
There are many Django courses in udemy. Why I choose this course because of the voice. I prefer to have instructor from India because their voice is very professional and soft. It make me excited to listen again and again without any headache. Many British and us people's are here making Django course but when I listen that voice I feel like too much tension and cannot concentrate to any topic. They make so much difficult for me everything. 
I just completed 60% of this course and it make me too much excited to learn more and more. in future I will try to buy courses from Indian instructor only as I have past experience from other English speaking guy. 
This course is best to me...
